Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Genetic Determinants of MammalianLlimb Biodiversity
Award.AbstractNarration: A major goal of biology is to identify the processes that shape the evolution of form and structure. To pursue this important goal, this project will take an innovative, comparative approach to investigate how evolutionary changes during limb development (the process by which the limb forms) contribute to the generation of the divergent limbs of three mammals: bats, opossums, and mice. The mammal limb is an ideal system with which to pursue this goal because the way that a mammal feeds, moves and behaves is dependent upon the form of its limbs. As such, from the wings of bats to the flippers of whales to the hooves of horses, the diversification of the mammal limb has been crucial to the ecological and evolutionary success of the group. Through use of traditional and next generation genetic analyses, this project will identify the specific changes in gene expression (e.g., when genes are turned on and off, and at what levels) that initiate and drive the divergence of limb form among mammalian species. This knowledge will vertically advance our understanding of how the process of development constrains and facilitates the evolution of certain limb forms, and thereby impacts mammalian evolution. Furthermore, as humans are mammals, this project will directly advance our understanding of the processes that have shaped our own evolutionary history.

POR.DRECONTENT:
From bat wings to horse hooves, mammalian limb diversification has been crucial to the evolutionary success of the group. Indirect evidence from studies of mammalian limb evolution suggests that mammalian limb diversification has not occurred primarily by the evolution of new genes, but by differential expression (i.e., turning on or off, or altering levels) of existing genes shared by all mammals and inherited from an ancestral genetic toolkit. However, the specific genes that are responsible for limb diversification remain unknown for most mammalian groups, as does the degree to which the nature of development predisposes the production of certain limb forms instead of others. To address these critical gaps in our knowledge, we performed the first comprehensive, multi-species comparison of the genetic regulation of developing mammalian limbs.

 

To identify genes that underlie mammalian limb diversification, we used techniques such as high-throughput RNA sequencing and whole-mount in situ hybridization to visualize and quantify patterns of gene expression in the developing arms and legs of pigs, bats, opossums, and mice. With this approach we identified several genes that are expressed differently (e.g., in different places in the limb, at different times, or at different levels) in limbs with different shapes, and likely contribute to the generation of these differences in form. These genes include transcription factors such as the HoxA and HoxD genes, and signaling factors such as BMPs, FGFs, and SHH. Consistent with our findings, when the normal expression of any of these genes is disrupted in mice, the resulting mice display altered limb shapes.

 

When we analyzed our gene expression data as a whole, we found that the earliest development of the limb (i.e., initial outgrowth and patterning) is conserved within and among species, but diverges shortly thereafter. To explore the cause of this conservation in early limb development, we built and perturbed computer-based gene interaction networks (i.e., models of the ways in which genes interact to drive development) for early and late limb development, and through computational analyses found that the early network is more robust to perturbations (i.e., alterations in the levels of genes in the network). We then quantified levels of genes within these networks within populations (i.e., in multiple individuals from the same species), and found that they vary less at earlier limb stages. We also found that variation in gene expression levels among individuals within a population and species are correlated. Taken together, these findings suggest that the robust nature of the gene interaction network driving early limb development buffers population-level variation in gene expression early in limb development. As natural selection can only act on the variation that is present in a population, this buffering also likely constrains the evolution of early limb development among mammalian species. This finding helps explain why mammalian limb diversification preferentially involves aspects of limb form that are laid down late in development (e.g., number of fingers or toes) rather than those that are laid down earlier (e.g., the number of limb segments, such as the upper arm, forearm, and hand).

 

Through its many findings, this project has yielded insights into the fundamental developmental mechanisms that control and shape mammalian limb evolution, and provides a framework for similar projects in different systems. The project has demonstrated that mammalian limb diversification has repeatedly occurred through changes in the expression of a limited suite of developmentally important genes acting later in limb development.
